title: Conservation of momentum - spaceship breaks apart

content.question: A spaceship of mass <math alttext="3 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mi>m</mi></math> is in deep space, far from any other objects, traveling with speed <math alttext="3 v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn><mi>v</mi></math> to the left, as shown in the top figure. The spaceship separates into two pieces, with masses <math alttext="2 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></math> and <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>, as shown in the bottom figure. The piece with mass <math alttext="2 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></math> moves to the left with speed <math alttext="4 v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><mi>v</mi></math>. Why does the piece of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> move to the left with speed <math alttext="v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>v</mi></math>?

choices.label: An external force on the system slows down the piece of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>.
An external force on the system increases the speed of the piece of mass <math alttext="2 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></math>.
There is no external force on the system so the momentum of the system must remain constant.
There is no external force on the system so kinetic energy must remain constant.

content.answer: There is no external force on the system so the momentum of the system must remain constant.
